concern:
So this is a long story and I'm currently in a bit of a unique situation because of which there's no one irl who i can ask for reliable advice so as much as reddit is really not the place to be asking for advice on life changing decisions i've got no other options and here we go.

**TDLR:  was a good student, went to horrible uni and tried to survive. now burnt out, looking to transfer but bc of horrid uni application is fucked. thinking of dropping out want to know abt how likelihood of job opportunities for foreign drop-outs. read passages marked \* for a longer summary**

**\*** The story basically goes that, I am an Indian citizen, but i've lived my whole life abroad so i know as much about India as ur next door neighbour + like 5%, okay. At the end of high school, I blindly trusted my parents' suggestion and got into and started attending a top 10 indian uni which has now become the single worst decision i've ever made in my entire life.

As it turned out, my uni is 100% fucked up. I could go on abt it for days but we don't have time to give a short summary of the vibes: extreme mismanagement of an institution, horrible facilities/classrooms, no sense of academic integrity, poor teaching, no sort of proper functioning basic 'services' like student welfare or career counselors provided, straight up illegal shit like holding classes in a construction site, the fact that you DON'T HAVE WIFI NOR DOES MOBILE DATA WORK BC NETWORK IS SO BAD on campus, the list goes on.

Getting back to my situation, my first year was online and EVERYONE cheated on EVERYTHING but I didn't know how to so I didn't and ended up with the lower side of decent kinda grades (mainly bc most of the syllabus was geared to start off from what was taught in the Indian curriculum that I obv didn't study and so there were large gaps in my knowledge that I wasn't even aware of). For detail, I averaged a 8.33/10 CGPA.

In my 2nd year, we went irl, I got my shit together, worked super hard but bc there is literally no sense of fair grading and cheating is rampant at my uni, so my efforts have only given mediocre results. (I got a 8.73/10 GPA in that sem, now averaging 8.46). This added with overwork (my uni is 6 days a week, 1 month holiday for summer, 1 week for winter, sometimes we do 7 days a week working and the semesters are back-to-back i.e. after the last day of sem 3, the next day is sem 4), I am super burned out rn with v low morale.

**\*** I've decided to transfer but I have a v weak application, I only focused on studying and I do computer science so I need projects/stuff to appear as a suitable candidate. I am generally quiet and mainly focused on self-learning bc of my low-quality classes so my letter of recommendations is also super weak. Ofc i do have potential, i am smart, i am hard working, i am capable. But my situation for the past 2 years has been HORRENDOUS and unfortunately no uni is going to understand that. After all i go to a top10 uni, hundreds of fully capable candidates graduate from there every year and i am the only one making excuses.

**\*** My only other option is to drop out. But my main priority is to leave India bc I cannot live here on my own like i don't know the language or the customs, etc and unlike every other country i've lived in you can't just google get straight forward answers for things in India which is the only survival method i've learnt. Which basically means if I drop out, I would have to learn computer science on my own and get a job abroad and i've never heard of anyone do that or the prospects of that path so I am super unsure.

This post has been an absolute mess but if anyone could help i'd appreciate it so so much.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you may have.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really overwhelmed with my uni situation and some big decisions I’ve gotta make, and I’m not sure where to even start unpacking it all.
That sounds really tough, and I'm glad you're reaching out for support. What aspects of university life are causing the most overwhelm for you right now?

Hey, it’s mostly the fact that I feel stuck in a really bad academic environment that’s just draining me. I’m also super stressed about whether to keep pushing through or make a drastic change, and I’m scared I’ll mess up either way.

That sounds incredibly stressful, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling stuck and uncertain. It must be really tough to feel like you're in an environment that's draining you, and also having to worry about making a decision that feels so high-stakes.
Yeah, it’s like I’m caught between a rock and a hard place, you know? I just don’t know if I can keep going like this, but I’m also terrified of what happens if I step away.

It's clear that you're feeling really torn between two difficult options. I wonder, what would your life look like if you stayed in your current academic environment, and how might that compare to the life you'd have if you decided to step away?

Honestly, if I stay, I think I’d just keep feeling more drained and frustrated, like I’m wasting my time in a place that’s not helping me grow. If I step away, I’m worried I’d be throwing away everything I’ve worked for and might struggle to figure out what’s next, especially since I don’t have a solid plan.

It's really brave of you to share these fears and uncertainties. You've clearly been giving this a lot of thought, and it sounds like you're trying to weigh the potential consequences of both paths. I'm curious, what do you think your life would look like in 5 years if you stayed in your current academic environment, and what might it look like if you decided to step away?

Man, if I stay in this environment for another few years, I feel like in 5 years I’d probably just be bitter and burned out, maybe with a degree but no real skills or passion left. If I step away now, I’m not sure, like I could see myself struggling for a bit but maybe finding a path that actually works for me, though I’m scared it could also mean I’m just lost with no degree and no direction.

It's really courageous of you to consider these possibilities, and I can see how both paths carry their own risks and uncertainties. What values or goals do you think are most important to you right now, and how might they help guide your decision-making?

Honestly, I think what matters most to me right now is finding a path where I can actually grow and feel like I’m building something meaningful, not just grinding through for a piece of paper. I also value stability, though, and I’m scared of losing that if I make a risky move, so I’m just torn on how to balance those two things.

It sounds like you're caught between valuing growth and stability, which are both important goals. I'm wondering if there might be a way to find a balance between these two values, or if one feels more urgent right now?

Yeah, I think growth feels a bit more urgent right now because I’m just so stuck and frustrated where I am, like I can’t keep going like this without losing myself. But at the same time, stability is always nagging at me, ‘cause I don’t wanna end up with nothing to show for all this struggle, you know?

I hear how important both growth and stability are to you, and it's understandable that you're feeling torn between them. Let's see if we can brainstorm some ways to address both of these values, even if they don't seem directly aligned at the moment. For example, could there be a way to explore new paths that might offer some growth while still maintaining a certain level of stability? Or perhaps there are small steps you could take to start moving towards growth without completely giving up stability?

Honestly, I’d love to find a way to balance both, but I’m not even sure where to start with that. Like, maybe there’s a way to explore some side projects or online courses for growth while sticking it out at uni for stability, but I’m just so drained already, I don’t know if I can handle more on my plate, you know?

It's clear you're really trying to find a way to honor both of these important values, and that takes a lot of courage. Let's break this down into smaller steps - could we start by exploring one or two small, manageable side projects or courses that might offer some sense of growth without overwhelming you? That way, you can test the waters without feeling like you're taking on too much at once.

Yeah, I think starting small could work, like maybe just one online course or a tiny project that doesn’t take up too much time. I’m just worried I’ll still feel stretched thin, but I guess I won’t know until I try, right?

It sounds like you've made a great start by identifying that growth feels more urgent, but stability is also a priority. By considering small, manageable side projects or online courses, you're taking a brave step towards honoring both of your values. Remember, you don't need to have it all figured out right now. Take it one step at a time, and trust that you can always adjust your approach as you go. Keep in mind that it's okay to feel stretched thin, but you can take breaks when you need to. You've got this, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's schedule a follow-up session to check in on your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plan.
Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement and the reminder to take it slow. I’ll give it a shot with something small and see how it feels, and I’m glad we can check in again soon.
